title: force spack to use dependencies it already installed, regardless of dependency's dependencies being updated
body:
I'm almost certain this is a duplicate, but I'm not finding the answer and I've been battling `qt` for too long now...

I want to install something that depends on `python`.  In my `packages.yaml` I have

```yaml
packages:
  python:
    variants: +tk
    version: [3.5.2]
```

this **will** get picked up, in terms of version and variant preferences:


but it won't use my existing one because the `python@3.5.2` dependencies updated since I installed mine (e.g. `readline`):

```console
$ spack find -ldfv python@3.5.2
==> 1 installed packages.
-- linux-fedora23-x86_64 / gcc@5.3.1 ----------------------------
luqlyqj    python@3.5.2%gcc+tk~ucs4
a6qdjqi        ^bzip2@1.0.6%gcc
foj2ppl        ^ncurses@6.0%gcc
xchnwyz        ^openssl@1.0.2j%gcc
32kujej            ^zlib@1.2.8%gcc+pic
o2e24g6        ^readline@6.3%gcc
5cqkjir        ^sqlite@3.8.5%gcc
4etsohm        ^tcl@8.6.5%gcc
g2w57vw        ^tk@8.6.5%gcc+X
rd3bid7            ^libx11@1.6.3%gcc
e2skinc                ^libxcb@1.12%gcc
eqz4y2j                    ^libpthread-stubs@0.3%gcc
zpzzo6z                    ^libxau@1.0.8%gcc
wwc5mx3                    ^libxdmcp@1.1.2%gcc
```

Is the only way to guarantee that my my `python@3.5.2` is used **always** to explicitly enumerate every version of every package that was used to make it in the first place?  I know there's a lot going on with changing the concretizer right now, I'm just looking for how to guarantee some of my core packages that I do not want **ever** want to reinstall get used (either because I changed them, like python, or because they take forever to compile...)?  Really regretting that `git pull` right now ... and I don't want to have to keep remembering to hack `libxcb` and `xcb-proto` x0
